facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 757 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil APPEAL No. 757 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Gujarat High Court judgment and order dated 28th May 1963 in Special Civil Application No. 419 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order, dated the 28th May, 1963 of the Gujarat High Court in Special Civil Application No. 419 of 1963.

facts.text: Gujarat High Court dismissed the application in limine on May 28, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: dated May 28, 1963, dismissing in limine an application filed by the appellant under Art. 226 of the Constitution. The facts material for the purposes of this appeal may be briefly stated.

facts.text: Appellant was a permanent employee of the State Transport Corporation, Gujarat.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was a permanent employee of the State Transport Corporation, Gujarat, hereinafter referred to as the Corporation.

facts.text: Appellant employed as a Writer in the Visnagar Depot of the Corporation in Mehsana District.

anchor.surface_text: At the material time he was employed as a Writer in the Visnagar Depot of the Corporation in Mahasana District.

facts.text: On January 15, 1962, appellant applied to Divisional Controller, State Transport, Mehsana, for 15 days leave for personal work.

anchor.surface_text: On January 15, 1962, the appellant applied to the Divisional Controller, State Transport, Mahasana, for leave for 15 days on the ground that he had to attend to his personal work.

facts.text: On January 16, 1962, appellant was transferred from Visnagar to Ambaji where there was a vacancy in Depot Manager's office.

anchor.surface_text: On January 16, 1962, he was transferred from Visnagar to Ambaji where there was a vacancy in the office of the Depot Manager.

facts.text: On January 31, 1962, formal order transferring appellant from Visnagar to Ambaji passed, directed to join duty at Ambaji.

anchor.surface_text: On January 31, 1962, a formal order transferring the appellant from Visnagar to Ambaji was passed, and he was directed to join duty at Ambaji.

facts.text: On January 31, 1962, appellant applied for extension of leave on medical grounds, refused by order dated February 15, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: On that date, the appellant applied for extension of leave on medical grounds but his request was refused by an order, dated February 15, 1962.

facts.text: Appellant directed to report for duty at Ambaji within 48 hours of receipt of notice, failing which removed from service.

anchor.surface_text: He was directed to report for duty at Ambaji within 48 hours of the receipt of numberice failing which, he was warned, he would be removed from service.

facts.text: On March 3, 1962, appellant wrote to Divisional Controller intimating inability to join duty as still not well, enclosed medical certificate.

anchor.surface_text: On March 3, 1962, the appellant wrote a letter to the Divisional Controller intimating him of his inability to join duty as he was still number well. To this letter, he enclosed a medical certificate.

facts.text: By order dated March 9, 1962, services of appellant terminated with effect from January 16, 1962, on ground of long absence.

anchor.surface_text: By an order, dated March 9, 1962, the services of the appellant were terminated with effect from January 16, 1962, on the ground of long absence.

facts.text: On March 17, 1962, appellant made representation to Divisional Controller.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant made a representation to the Divisional Controller on March 17, 1962 and thereafter preferred an appeal to the General Manager of the Corporation.

facts.text: Representation and appeal to General Manager rejected.

anchor.surface_text: Both of them were rejected. A further appeal preferred by him to the L9SUPCI/66--4 4 2 appellate Committee was also unsuccessful.

facts.text: Appeal to Appellate Committee unsuccessful; Committee held leave applications made to evade joining duty at Ambaji.

anchor.surface_text: A further appeal preferred by him to the L9SUPCI/66--4 4 2 appellate Committee was also unsuccessful. The Committee held that the leave applications of the appellant were made only with a view to evade joining duty at Ambaji.

facts.text: Appellant applied to Gujarat High Court under Arts. 226 and 227, impleading Divisional Controller as respondent, for writ of certiorari to quash dismissal order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant applied to the High Court of Gujarat under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution, impleading the Divisional Controller as respondent, for the issue of a writ of certriorari to quash the order of dismissal.

facts.text: High Court petition dismissed in limine on May 28, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: His petition was dismissed in limine on May 28, 1963.

facts.text: On June 17, 1963, appellant applied for certificate to appeal to Supreme Court, refused.

anchor.surface_text: On June 17, 1963, the appellant applied for a certificate to appeal to this Court but it was refused. Thereafter he applied for special leave and that was granted by this Court.

facts.text: Special leave granted by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter he applied for special leave and that was granted by this Court.

facts.text: Respondent is autonomous statutory Corporation under Road Transport Corporations Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated at the outset that the respondent is an autonomous statutory Corporation formed under the provisions of the Road Transport Corporations Act, 1950.

facts.text: It is not disputed that appellant could not invoke Art. 311 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the appellant companyld number invoke the provisions of Art. 311 of the Constitution.

facts.text: No charge was framed against appellant nor given opportunity to show cause.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that numbercharge was framed against him number was he given an opportunity to show cause.

facts.text: Regulations govern service conditions of Corporation employees.

anchor.surface_text: We may, at this stage, read the relevant regulations which admittedly govern the service companyditions of the employees of the G Corporation.

issues.text: whether the appellant could invoke the provisions of Art. 311 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that the appellant could not invoke the provisions of Art. 311 of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether the appellant was entitled to an opportunity to show cause against the proposed punishment as required by regulation No. 61 of the Regulations which govern the service conditions of the employees of the Corporation

anchor.surface_text: The short question for determination in the appeal is whether the appellant was entitled to an opportunity to show cause against the proposed punishment as required by regulation No. 61 of the Regulations which govern the service conditions of the employees of the Corporation.

issues.text: whether the termination itself was not by way of punishment and the only right was to two months pay in lieu of notice under regulation No. 61

anchor.surface_text: It is contended for the respondent that though the order of termination referred to long absence as the cause of termination, the termination itself was not by way of punishment and the only right of the appellant was to two months pay in lieu of notice under regulation No. 61, that assuming that the termination was by way of punishment, the appellant, as would be evident from the correspondence and the circumstances of the case, had been given an opportunity to show cause

issues.text: whether there was in fact and in substance compliance with the rules of natural justice

anchor.surface_text: and that there was in fact and in substance compliance with the rules of natural justice. We may, at this stage, read the relevant regulations which admittedly govern the service conditions of the employees of the Corporation.

issues.text: whether irregular attendance, absence without leave and without reasonable cause and failure, without sufficient cause, to report for duty amount to acts of misconduct

anchor.surface_text: Clause 3 defines two classes of offences named acts of misconduct and minor lapses and delinquencies, respectively and sub cl. ii of cl. 3 states inter alia that the misconducts are those specified in Schedule A. Regulations 38 and 40 provide that irregular attendance, absence without leave and without reasonable cause and failure, without sufficient cause, to report, when directed, for duty amount to acts of misconduct.

issues.text: whether a person against whom action is proposed to be taken for any act of misconduct shall be provided with a copy of the charge or charges as well as a statement of allegations that have been made against him

anchor.surface_text: 4 b . A person against whom action is proposed to be taken for any act of misconduct, shall be provided with a copy of the charge or charges as well as a statement of allegations that have been made against him, and over which enquiry is being held. Clause 3 defines two classes of offences named acts of misconduct

issues.text: whether the order of termination contravenes the provisions of cl. 4 b of the Regulation and the principles of natural justice

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the appellant was entitled to an opportunity to show cause against the action proposed to be taken against him. The order of termination passed against the appellant is bad in law since it contravenes the provisions of cl. 4 b of the Regulation and also the principles of natural justice.

issues.text: whether a writ of certiorari will issue quashing the order of dismissal

anchor.surface_text: In all the circumstances of the case, we are satisfied that the impugned order must be quashed. A writ of certiorari will accordingly issue quashing the order of dismissal, but this will not preclude the respondent from making a fresh enquiry against the appellant after giving him reasonable opportunity to show cause

holdings.text: The appellant could not invoke the provisions of Art. 311 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that the appellant could not invoke the provisions of Art. 311 of the Constitution.

holdings.text: Irregular attendance, absence without leave and without reasonable cause and failure, without sufficient cause, to report for duty amount to acts of misconduct.

anchor.surface_text: Regulations 38 and 40 provide that irregular attendance, absence without leave and without reasonable cause and failure, without sufficient cause, to report, when directed, for duty amount to acts of misconduct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of Clause 3 Schedule A, Regulations 38 and 40.

holdings.text: A person against whom action is proposed to be taken for any act of misconduct shall be provided with a copy of the charge or charges as well as a statement of allegations.

anchor.surface_text: 4 b . A person against whom action is proposed to be taken for any act of misconduct, shall be provided with a copy of the charge or charges as well as a statement of allegations that have been made against him, and over which enquiry is being held.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct quote and interpretation of Clause 4(b) Schedule A.

holdings.text: No charge was framed against the appellant nor was he given an opportunity to show cause or any enquiry conducted.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that no charge was framed against him nor was he given an opportunity to show cause.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admitted fact applied to procedural requirements.

holdings.text: The appellant was entitled to an opportunity to show cause against the action proposed to be taken against him.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the appellant was entitled to an opportunity to show cause against the action proposed to be taken against him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Long absence constitutes misconduct requiring procedural safeguards under Cl. 4(b) and natural justice.

holdings.text: The order of termination is bad in law as it contravenes cl. 4(b) of the Regulations and principles of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: The order of termination passed against the appellant is bad in law since it contravenes the provisions of cl. 4 b of the Regulation and also the principles of natural justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No opportunity provided despite misconduct allegation; violates mandatory regulation and natural justice.

holdings.text: A writ of certiorari will issue quashing the order of dismissal, without precluding fresh enquiry after compliance with Cl. 4(b).

anchor.surface_text: A writ of certiorari will accordingly issue quashing the order of dismissal, but this will not preclude the respondent from making a fresh enquiry against the appellant after giving him reasonable opportunity to show cause

holdings.reasoning_summary: Impugned order invalid; certiorari appropriate remedy under Arts. 226/227, with liberty for compliant re-enquiry.
